body: Thanks for the pull request and the help!  I've reviewed the changes and they look good to me.  Can you create a JIRA at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU and attach a patch with these changes?  We have a wiki page at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/DATAFU/Contributing+to+Apache+DataFu that describes how to create the patch.

Hey sorry, I totally missed this pull request.  Thanks for the contribution!  This definitely seems useful.  I have wanted this exact UDF actually but hadn't gotten around to writing it :)  Please write unit tests as well.  Can you also file a JIRA at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU and attach a patch.  For instructions on how to generate a patch see https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/DATAFU/Contributing+to+Apache+DataFu.
Note: JIRA was filed at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU-65
Here is the JIRA ticket https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU-79
I have created the JIRA ticket for this pull request (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU-80) and attached the patch to it. Hope this is useful.
Great thanks :)  I will take a look.

Copy of comments from Jira:

In SparkDFUtils.scala:
 - dedup2 could use some additional description to differentiate it from dedup.
- flatten is missing documentation
- for broadcastJoinSkewed, the description of the numberCustsToBroadcast field isn't clear to me
- joinWithRange could use some more documentation. For example, the fields are not all documented. It's not immediately obvious to me what DECREASE_FACTOR does and why it should have a default value of 2^8.
- Also, joinWithRange seems characteristically different from the other in this file, as it's a bit more use-case specific. Maybe later it would make sense to move this to a separate file.
@matthayes , @eyala - I've fixed according to your comments.
wrong base
re-opening after adding ScalaPythonBridge functionallity
Merged the commit from Feb 18th

I didn't take care of all of Russell's comments, but I had to make some changes in the tests in order for them to pass in all the Spark/Scala versions I included (Spark from 2.1.0 to 2.4.0, Scala 2.10 and 2.11).

In order to build and run the tests for all the different versions, you can use the bash script [build_and_test_spark.sh](https://github.com/apache/datafu/blob/spark-tmp/datafu-spark/build_and_test_spark.sh). It takes a little less than an hour to run and test on all the versions.
@rjurney, I've reformatted all the code with Spark's scalastyle.xml. I believe this should solve most of the code style issues.

+1

I reviewed the recent code changes and these look good to me.  I am able to build the JAR via `assemble`.

However I did run into an issue running the tests that I'm still investigating.  This may be environmental.

```
> Task :datafu-spark:test

datafu.spark.TestScalaPythonBridge > pyfromscala.py FAILED
    java.lang.RuntimeException at TestScalaPythonBridge.scala:72

datafu.spark.TestScalaPythonBridge > SparkDFUtilsBridge FAILED
    java.lang.RuntimeException at TestScalaPythonBridge.scala:72

24 tests completed, 2 failed
```

This seems to be the relevant info about one of the failures (they both seem to be the same issue):

```
datafu.spark.TestScalaPythonBridge > pyfromscala.py FAILED
    java.lang.RuntimeException: python bridge error: 
Python 3.6.0 (default, Jun  6 2018, 13:47:36) 
    
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 9.1.0 (clang-902.0.39.2)] on darwin
    
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
    
>>> >>> ... ... ... ... ... ... Traceback (most recent call last):
    
  File "<stdin>", line 2, in <module>
    
NameError: name 'execfile' is not defined
        at org.apache.spark.deploy.SparkPythonRunner.execFile(SparkPythonRunner.scala:135)
        at org.apache.spark.deploy.SparkPythonRunner.runPyFile(SparkPythonRunner.scala:50)
        at datafu.spark.ScalaPythonBridgeRunner.runPythonFile(ScalaPythonBridge.scala:65)
        at datafu.spark.TestScalaPythonBridge$.getNewRunner(TestScalaPythonBridge.scala:41)
        at datafu.spark.TestScalaPythonBridge.datafu$spark$TestScalaPythonBridge$$runner$lzycompute(TestScalaPythonBridge.scala:72)
        at datafu.spark.TestScalaPythonBridge.datafu$spark$TestScalaPythonBridge$$runner(TestScalaPythonBridge.scala:72)
```

Any idea what's wrong?

Okay I think I get what's going on.  SparkPythonRunner must be assuming that Python 2.x is being used, however I am using Python 3.6.  When I switch to Python 2.7 it works.  I think for now we should add a note to the README about Python version support and add a TODO to make it work with Python 3.x.  There is no reason why it shouldn't work on Python 3.x right?
Anyways from my perspective I think we're good to merge in.  @rjurney any other comments?
Merged
Russell can you close this now since it is merged already?
Already merged separately.
Already merged
Closing this as JIRA was filed and resolved as won't fix.

Hello! I'm glad to see your contributions. I went over the first commit before you added more (it looks fine), but I see you've made more changes - we might want to split them into their respective projects to keep things clear in the git history.

Do you use datafu-pig/hourglass yourself? How did you test these changes?
Hi sorry for the late reply! How do you want me to split the changes?

You can divide it by project - maybe leave the datafu-pig commits here, and make a new PR with the datafu-hourglass ones.

How did you test this? When I try to build your branch I get a compilation error because of the lombok.NonNull annotation.
After checking the document of lombok.NonNull, I think it's better to leave the code unchanged so I will open another PR without lombok.NonNul.

You can either open a new PR or just remove the change from this one, either option is fine.

But are you successfully running all the tests? If you have changes that aren't executed in the tests it's a good idea to add a new case or input in order to include them.

I think you're correct in your analysis - this does make the join basically an inner join. There are two issues that need to be addressed before we can merge this, one theoretical and one practical.

1) I think making it a working left outer join is a good idea, but I don't want to change the existing behavior. What do you think about adding a parameter like the Spark join type? (@uzadude, what do you think?) Then we can make an inner join remain the default.

2) In order to merge it, we would need you to modify/add a test so that your code can be checked automatically. (this is crucial for keeping our project maintainable)
sure, let's add a `joinType` parameter like in the skew join methods. let's keep it backward compatible.

Hi, I agree with your suggestions, the initial change set was just to spark (pun intended) the discussion and as my braindump if someone would like to take the issue faster than I was able to. Now I a have a bit of time and will happily provide requested changes.

Well, during testing I actually found a pretty serious issue... if the record falls into `decreased_range_single`, but `range_start` and `range_end` does not contain `single` then I would need to replace the joined data with nulls (and deduplicate) which makes for a significantly harder operation than I anticipated.

Will mark the PR as closed for now but will provide all of my current changes to the branch, so we can return to them later if we need to.

I think you're right. I would say that it's still worth doing ... but if there are multiple records with the same "key" (the column provided as _single_) I don't see how the records without a range can be safely deduplicated.
If you want to submit just your test cases, I've made [a JIRA issue for generic test improvements](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU-164).
@eyala please check this out.

Hi @benraha ,

After you opened this PR I managed to get our GitHub to build and test for different versions of Spark and Scala, and I tried your code out locally. It looks like it doesn't pass compilation in Spark 2.1.x, which we support. But since Spark 2.1.x is so old, I'm willing to merge your PR and drop support for it.

I will ask about this in our dev discussion group.

Looks good to me. The only improvement I can think of is maybe copying some of your detailed description into the method docs so it will be easier for people to understand when to use this new parameter.
Hi @eyala , added a comment in the code to the place I've copied it from
Great, I can see that your commit triggered the build (which indeed fails for Spark 2.1.3). So far no one has objected to dropping support for this version, so we will probably merge it in soon.
I changed the commit name to include the Jira issue for this (DATAFU-166) and merged it manually, so I'm closing this PR

I pushed a change in the versions we test for, but I don't know why the retriggered testing on Github isn't including my change. Testing locally shows that all our (currently) supported Spark/Scala versions pass successfully.

I will merge this in - I'm going to change the commit name to include the JIRA issue I opened for it ([DATAFU-165](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DATAFU-165)).
Squashed and merged manually.
@eyala Kindly review this PR.
Merged into master

HI @eyala ,

Just curious how this PR is showing closed but the commit has been merged. 

Actually this way it doesn't showcase in my contributions stats.

Is it something i missed while creating the PR which i need to take care in next one?

No, you didn't do anything wrong, @arpitbhardwaj !

I merged it manually in order to add the name of the Jira ticket to the commit, and so that the commit would appear as "signed off" by me - if I used the GitHub merge PR feature I wouldn't have been able to do these things.

However, the commit should appear in your GitHub contribution history. Maybe the email you used in the commit isn't in your GitHub profile? If that's the case, after you add it, GitHub will know that all the commits done by this email are yours.

It seems to me like there are some changes in what is being logged. You can see this by comparing the gradle build results in _datafu-spark/build/test-results_ (between the master branch and yours).

For example, this line is missing in DataframeOpsTests:

`WARN apache.spark.SparkContext - Using an existing SparkContext; some configuration may not take effect.
`

And some messages with level _WARN hive.metastore.ObjectStore_ from TestScalaPythonBridge, and _WARN hive.metastore.ObjectStore_ from UdafTests.

If it's just the default logging level in the tests, I think it's fine ... but if it will lead to a change in actual usage then less so.
ok let me check the cause for missing lines

@eyala Thanks for pointing it out. 

Found the cause it was happening due to missing log4j2 properties in test resources. 
I have added it now and removed the older one. 

Logger lines are now as it is master. Please verify and let me know.

Hi @arpitbhardwaj , looks good.

Did you see what I wrote about adding your email to your GitHub account? I do want your last commit to be included on your profile. At any rate, I will merge this one as it is, so the PR itself gets counted.
@eyala Yes i corrected the email in this PR commit. In last PR commit there was some other email got attached wrongly.
Great work +1
Weird ... it looks like renaming the master branch has canceled our CI. I'll push a fix so it runs.

looks good!
please add a short summary description to the PR, and also mention if it is breaking backward API compatibility (in python/scala).
Looks like nokogiri is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.
I took care of the conflicts (I changed some of the build scripts and caused them) and manually merged this.
Superseded by #39.
Merging this; the failing test is because the main branch is still using (now unsupported) Python 2.x, and this change doesn't affect whether the tests pass or fail.
You might also want to update the DOAP description to take account of DataFu Spark

Did you specify that DataFu build with Spark 3.3 or 3.4? I think your PR assumes a newer interface of _DeclarativeAggregate_ than what we have currently, and that's why the build is failing in our CI.

I'm planning on pushing code that will upgrade us to these versions, so that will probably make your PR pass tests.
Looks good!

Looks like after the last commit our CI passes, so now this works for Spark 3.0.x - 3.4.x. I'll merge it in.

Great job!
